Award.AwardTitle: Full-Scale Development of Peg + Cat: Early Learning of Math through Media

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research and development project explores the mechanisms that initiate and support innovation in early childhood education, especially in combining informal learning via public media and technology with teacher and family interactions to maximize children's math learning. Deliverables include 27 episodes of Peg+Cat, an animated math adventure series on PBS, 8 related online games and apps, summer math institutes and school-year training for preschool/Head Start teachers, and complementary activities and resources to support parent's knowledge and practice and student's engagement, interest, and learning of foundational math concepts. The research agenda will test several hypotheses regarding the strategies to extend teacher's math content knowledge and pedagogy and parent/ caregiver's understanding and valuing of math. A key question will focus on how coupled learning opportunities (professional development for teachers, transmedia, and support for families) enable and sustain children's engagement and learning in math.

Formative evaluation of the media components will use focus groups of 3-5 year olds to assure develerables are engaging and accessible. The summative evaluation by Rockman et al will focus on how well the project met its overall goals including the project implementation, and impacts on Head Start teachers, parents/caregivers, and preschoolers.

The project's transmedia deliverables will reach millions of preschoolers through daily PBS broadcasts and online games and apps. Fifty Head Start teachers will participate in the two-year professional development program and will be using new content knowledge and pedagogy to teach 550 Head Start children in southwest Pennsylvania and engage their parents/caregivers. The Head Start infrastructure will provide further dissemination of the project's findings and resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background 

Early exposure to STEM, including math, supports children’s academic growth, cultivates early critical thinking and reasoning skills, and enhances later interest in STEM careers (National Research Council, 2011). While all children have the capacity for math achievement, teachers often do not regard math as critical to young learners’ development, and many lack the confidence to help children learn math. Early childhood educators also often have negative attitudes and low self-efficacy regarding math and inadequate knowledge of math content (Clements & Sarama, 2009). This may explain why they spend, on average, only 7% of instructional time on math (Farmer, 2012). Programs designed to improve early childhood educators’ confidence and pedagogical content knowledge have the potential to enhance children’s math learning in early childhood education (ECE) classrooms.

Project Overview

Peg + Cat Early Learning of Math Through Media (ELM2) was a three-year project, funded by the National Science Foundation Advancing Informal STEM Learning program. The project encompassed production of Peg + Cat, an animated math-based PBS television series for preschoolers and complementary games and apps, piloting of a professional development (PD) institute for Head Start teachers, development of family engagement resources, and research to advance the field’s understanding of how to help teachers effectively support young children’s math engagement and learning.

Capitalizing on the existing infrastructure of a regional Head Start system, ELM2’s intensive 2-year, 20-day PD aimed to impact educators’ attitudes and confidence about math, pedagogical content knowledge, and instructional practices. It focused on developmentally appropriate math content including pre-number and number concepts, operations, geometry, and measurement, and addressed how to incorporate math into everyday routines. The PD integrated Peg + Cat media to deepen teachers’ knowledge of math content, to demonstrate how to use of Peg + Cat resources with children, and to provide a backdrop for families to engage mathematically with their children. The PD also addressed how to build families’ comfort and interest in math and bridge children’s math engagement in the classroom and at home. ELM2 was guided by five big ideas: 1) math is everywhere, 2) math is important, 3) everyone can learn and use math, 4) persistence in problem-solving is essential, and 5) math learning begins early in life, and adults should support and encourage it.    

Methods and Results

To understand the PD’s impact on teachers, families, and children, the ELM2 team administered content assessments, surveys, interviews, and classroom and PD observations. After participating in ELM2 PD, teachers’ pedagogical content knowledge of age-appropriate math content and confidence and self-efficacy in teaching math increased.  Teachers also integrated effective practices to support children’s mathematical learning in their classrooms. Observations revealed that teachers were adept at using a variety of modalities, effective facilitation, and frequent “math talk” with children. Parents reported increases in a) their engagement and conversations with their children around math, and b) attendance at Head Start math family engagement activities. Parents also reported that their children were showing more positive and persistent attitudes toward math by the end of the project. Finally, both parents and teachers reported increases in children’s understanding of specific math skills, math vocabulary use, and interest in math.

Conclusion and Implications 

ELM2 sought to combine robust teacher training in math content and in the facilitation of classroom and family engagement activities with transmedia resources that families could utilize at home. This cohesive approach resulted in positive outcomes for teachers, parents, and children. Findings have several implications for the ECE field. First, transmedia resources give teachers, parents, and children an approachable and fun way to experience math together. These resources effectively hold children’s attention, and help get families and teachers excited about math, too.  Second, administrative buy-in is key to successful PD in early math for early childhood educators. When administrators experienced ELM2 PD alongside teachers, both groups saw it as more valuable. Third, math instruction for early learners should include intentional exposure to math throughout the school day in a variety of contexts, as well as provide families with ideas and strategies to connect what children are doing in school to their everyday lives. Ultimately, this will help children build a solid foundation for future success in math.
